data.title: Melinda French Gates says she is resigning from Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation
data.meta_description: Melinda French Gates announced Monday she is resigning from her position as co-chair of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
data.text:
, who is the ex-wife ofbillionaire Bill Gates, announced Monday she is resigning from her position as co-chair of the .

She shared the news on social media, noting she made the decision "after careful thought and reflection."

This is not a decision I came to lightly," she wrote. "I am immensely proud of the foundation that Bill and I built together and of the extraordinary work it is doing to address inequities around the world. I care deeply about the foundation team, our partners around the world, and everyone who is touched by its work."

French Gates said the foundation is "in strong shape," noting it is in good hands with the nonprofit's "extremely capable" CEO Mark Suzman, as well as its executive leadership team and board of trustees.

This is the right move forward into the next chapter of my philanthropy," she wrote.

She also said under the terms of an agreement with her ex-husband, who she divorced in 2021, she will have "an additional $12.5 billion to commit" to her work on behalf of women and families in need.

"I will be sharing more about what that will look like in the near future," she wrote.

In a separate post on social media, Bill Gates thanked his ex-wife for "her critical contributions" to the foundation and said while he is "sorry" to see her leave, he is confident "she will have a huge impact in her future philanthropic work."

The couple co-founded the non-profit in 2000, with French Gates helping to shape strategies and initiatives in their work to improve global health and battle gender equality.

"Looking ahead, I remain fully committed to the Foundationâ€™s work across all our strategies, and to realizing the opportunities we have to continue improving the lives of millions around the world," Bill Gates wrote. "Our foundation team is incredibly strong and deeply passionate about our work, and under the leadership of Mark Suzman, and a committed board of trustees, I am confident we will keep making substantial progress on our mission to create a world where every person can live a healthy, productive life."

Suzman said the nonprofit will be changing its name to the Gates Foundation, with Bill Gates to become its sole chair.

French Gates has ranked on Forbes' annual list of the 100 Most Powerful Women at least 10 times starting in 2011. She and Gates share three children, including two daughters and a son.
